awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Math Cognition In Toddlers From Latino and White Families: Contributions Of Home Experiences With Mothers and Fathers
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposed research, led by a team of investigators from New York University, the University of Pittsburgh, and the University of Maryland, will address the persistent problem of low representation of particular US minorities in STEM fields. Already by school entry, children display striking individual differences in math skills that can set them on a path for high or low math performance and participation in STEM disciplines. Latino children, who are disproportionately from low-SES households, are largely vulnerable to delays in math in the school years relative to non-Latino white children, making it urgent to examine when and why this gap emerges. To this end, this project will examine the early math skills of 300 Latino and non-Latino White toddlers and their relation to the quantity and quality of math-related learning opportunities that mothers and fathers provide for their children during everyday interactions. In addition, mothers' and fathers' math abilities, attitudes toward math, and beliefs about the importance of math for children will be examined to determine which of these factors may explain variation in the provision of math-related learning opportunities in the home. Findings of this project will be communicated to educators, practitioners working with parents, staff at community agencies, and parents of young children. The project is funded by the EHR Core Research (ECR) program, which supports work that advances the fundamental research literature on STEM learning, research on workforce development, and research on broadening participation. 

The goals of this project are to advance science on early math cognition and aspects of the home environment that support math learning across three core systems: (1) the approximate number system (ANS), an imprecise, nonsymbolic representation of number, (2) the exact number system, a precise, symbolic representation of number, and (3) spatial math, a system that represents shapes, space, and relations among objects in space. These core systems of math are building blocks to mathematical cognition throughout the lifespan. This project will investigate core math skills in toddlers from Latino and non-Latino white backgrounds and the factors that contribute to individual differences. In a sample varying in ethnicity and SES, investigators will describe individual differences in mathematical cognition in 2- to 3-year-olds from Latino and non-Latino white backgrounds, document the roles of mothers' and fathers' math-related practices in children's math skills using new video coding tools and measure, test associations between parenting practices and toddler math skills, and identify the factors that explain variations in mothers' and fathers' math-related practices. This project will inform the design of interventions to support emerging math skills and address the participation of members of groups underrepresented in STEM related fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Math permeates the lives of young children. They argue about which pile of candy has the most. They count their fingers, toes, and spaces on board games. They orient triangles, rectangles and other blocks to fit shape-sorters and puzzles. These everyday behaviors around number and spatial concepts pave the way for later math skills. Indeed, already by school entry, many children exhibit delays in math skills, which can set them on a path for low math performance and low participation in STEM disciplines later Notably, the building blocks for learning math concepts occur in the everyday home environment, as toddlers engage with the people around them and are exposed to words and materials that reinforce an understanding of number and spatial concepts (such as hearing caregivers count cookies and playing with blocks of different sizes).

However, research on math cognition remains limited in several ways. First, it largely overlooks the toddler period-a time when children grow in their understanding of number (two, many), spatial features (circle, round), spatial relations (over, behind), and magnitudes/quantifiers (more, bigger), and begin to use words to refer to those concepts. Second, most studies target mothers’ interactions with children, leaving out the role of fathers in early math cognition. Finally, despite rapid growth in the US Latino population-and an urgent need address group disparities in the low participation of Latino individuals in STEM professions-researchers know little about the math skills and experiences of children from Spanish-speaking households.

To address these gaps, researchers from NYU, University of Pittsburgh, and University of Maryland observed toddlers interacting with their fathers and mothers from Spanish- and English-speaking homes, and tested toddlers on key aspects of math cognition. The project goals were to: (1) Describe differences among 2- to 3-year-old toddlers from Latino and non-Latino White backgrounds on their math skills. (2) Document associations between mothers and fathers’ parenting practices around math in relation to children’s emerging math skills and use of math words/phrases; (3) Identify factors that explain variations in mothers’ and fathers’ parenting practices and language use around math.

For Aim 1, we developed new fun, age-appropriate games to test toddlers’ number and spatial skills. For Aim 2, we video-recorded toddlers playing (separately) with mother and father with activities designed to elicit math-related language (e.g., shape sorter, magnet board with shapes, book about numbers, grocery shopping set with different numbers of food items). We augmented our focus on structured activities with observations of toddlers and caregivers at home going about their everyday activities. For Aim 3, parents reported on their attitudes around math, the skills they believed important for children to acquire, toys at home, childrearing values, and so on.

Findings revealed that-already by toddlerhood-large differences exist in children’s math skills and math-related interactions with mothers and fathers. Similarly, parents varied in their use of math language, although mothers and fathers overall did not differ in their math language to toddlers. Parents’ use of math language related to several measures of toddlers’ math skills, including how much children used math words themselves and their performance on assessments of spatial features (shape names) and spatial relations (e.g., words/phrases such as "under", "next to", "on top of"). Finally, several factors predicted parents’ engagement in math-related activities. As one example, mothers reported higher engagement in home math activities with toddlers (e.g., games around math, counting) than did fathers, but gender differences disappeared for parents who endorsed the importance of math for their children.

Collectively, this NSF funded project yielded several key products on toddlers developing understanding of math concepts. The Intellectual Merit includes: (1) dissemination of findings on how children’s interactions with mothers and fathers relate to their use of math words and growing understanding of math concepts; (2) the design and validation of new measures to test toddlers’ math skills; (3) development and open sharing of protocols (e.g., inventories of math words in English and Spanish) and research stimuli (illustrations that contain math concepts for remote studies of math talk); and (4) hundreds of videos openly-shared with authorized investigators on the video-repository Databrary to advance the science of math cognition. Broader Impacts include: (1) workshops for community members (e.g., parents, educators) on the importance of early math cognition for school readiness and ways to support such skills; (2) video clips (1-2 min) sent to parents’ cell phones with tips around math support; (3) translation of materials to Spanish for expansion of research and programming to the fastest-growing US population of children; and (4) research opportunities for undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral fellows (including Spanish-speaking, immigrant students), who gained expertise on toddler math cognition, behavioral coding, and language development, and had opportunities to network and collaborative on the creation of behavioral coding manuals and dissemination of findings at conferences and in publications.
